Jared Isaacman’s Project Athena: A Radical Plan to Restructure NASA’s Future Lunar and Mars Programs
item.description:
The article discusses Jared Isaacman’s leaked 62-page plan known as Project Athena, intended to reorganize NASA and reform its human spaceflight and exploration programs. Initially drafted when Isaacman was a leading candidate for NASA Administrator under President Trump, the document proposes deep structural changes across NASA centers and bold measures for lunar and Mars missions. Project Athena supports canceling the SLS rocket after the Artemis III mission while aiming to accelerate lunar landings to beat China. It suggests using SpaceX’s Starship and Blue Origin’s New Glenn as alternatives to the SLS.
In addition to lunar operations, the proposal outlines a Mars exploration initiative called Project Olympus, envisioned as a partnership with SpaceX to send multiple uncrewed Starships to Mars by 2026, establishing an initial base called Mars Discovery Base. item.title: Black leader criticizes immigrant Trump voters after immigration protection cuts
item.description: The recent decision by the Trump administration to end immigration protections for Haitians has sparked outrage within the migrant community. Felicia Persaud, a Caribbean-U.S.-based journalist, argues that this policy change is partly driven by pro-Trump immigrant voters who helped elect the former president. The termination of Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for Haiti is particularly impactful, as more than 500,000 Haitian immigrants in the U.S. face deportation after the policy expires in February 2026. Additionally, the Trump administration's review of Green Card holders from 19 countries, mostly non-white majority nations, signals a continued stance against immigrants of color. Persaud specifically targets the Haitian, Cuban, Somali, Venezuelan, and Hispanic immigrant groups who voted for Trump despite his xenophobic rhetoric. She warns that those who helped elect him are now facing the consequences of their support. The Trump administration’s immigration policies reflect a broade

item.title: Romanian President Nicuor Dan acknowledges ongoing corruption but notes some progress
item.description: In his National Day speech on December 1, 2025, Romanian President Nicuor Dan candidly admitted that Romania remains a corrupt country, affirming that public frustration and perception of rampant corruption are justified. Dan highlighted that although the state often appears unwilling to effectively combat corruption, the situation has improved compared to twenty years ago. He criticized corrupt individuals who appear on television giving moral lessons, which further fuels public outrage. Despite acknowledging setbacks such as declining living standards from the previous year and persistent weaknesses in public systems like education and healthcare, Dan also pointed out some progress. This includes infrastructure developments such as the construction of 500 kilometers of highways and new hospital buildings funded by EU programs. Furthermore, Dan referenced the cancellation of the 2024 presidential elections as a damaging event raising questions about Romania's democratic stability, men

item.title: Miebo: How a European $20 Eye Drop Became an $800 Prescription in the U.S.
item.description: The article exposes the extreme price disparity between an over-the-counter European eye drop and its costly U.S. counterpart. In Europe, EvoTears has been available since 2015 for around $20, while its U.S. version, Miebo—produced by Bausch & Lomb—costs over $800 per month. The piece argues that this discrepancy stems not from regulatory necessity, but from deliberate corporate manipulation of American drug approval laws. After obtaining exclusive rights to the drug in 2019, Bausch & Lomb chose to seek FDA approval as a prescription drug rather than pursue over-the-counter status. This decision allowed the company to patent the product, limit competition, and set exorbitant prices. Miebo’s sales exceeded $170 million in its first full year, far surpassing projections. The company’s justification—that FDA classification required rigorous testing—sidesteps the fact that the FDA’s criteria for nonprescription approval center on patient safety without doctor supervision, a threshold the p

item.title: AI, Labor Cuts, and the Contradictions of Capitalism: The Telefónica Case
item.description:
The article examines how artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming capitalist production and labor relations, using Telefónica’s massive layoff plan as a case study. It argues that AI not only replaces manual labor but also intellectual and creative work, pushing production costs toward zero while exposing capitalism’s structural contradictions. Telefónica’s plan to cut nearly 6,000 jobs in Spain—representing about a quarter of its workforce—forms part of a wider strategy to achieve efficiency, reduce debt, and redirect resources toward AI and cybersecurity. The move, however, signals a deeper shift: the company is replacing human control with data-driven management ('dataism'), maximizing profits through algorithmic oversight of labor and consumer behavior.
The article contends that this technological progress, while capable of producing material abundance, is being used to increase inequality rather than to improve collective welfare. In the short term, AI serves as capital’s we

item.title: Federal agents briefly detain woman in Key Largo before confirming U.S. citizenship
item.description: A woman driving through Key Largo early Wednesday morning was briefly detained by federal agents in a scene that raised concerns about possible profiling and the conduct of immigration enforcement. According to video taken by Miami Herald reporter David Goodhue, several masked agents pulled the screaming woman from her car near Pink Plaza at Mile Marker 103.4. In the footage, she repeatedly shouted that she was a U.S. citizen and pleaded for help as agents placed her in handcuffs. Goodhue stated that the encounter began with officers apparently asking for her identification. When she failed to produce it, the situation escalated quickly. A Monroe County Sheriff’s deputy was seen directing traffic while federal agents surrounded the vehicle. Witnesses said the agencies involved appeared to be ICE, Customs and Border Protection, and Border Patrol, with the sheriff’s office only providing support for public safety. item.title: Texas Families Seek Nationwide Injunction Against Unconstitutional Ten Commandments Displays in Schools
item.description:
A coalition of civil rights and secular organizations, including Americans United for Separation of Church and State, the ACLU, and the Freedom From Religion Foundation, has joined 18 multifaith and nonreligious Texas families in filing a class action lawsuit against Senate Bill 10. The law mandates that every Texas public school classroom display the King James version of the Ten Commandments. Federal courts have already deemed the measure unconstitutional in prior rulings, but Attorney General Ken Paxton continues to urge districts to ignore those decisions and put up the displays.
The new lawsuit, titled *Ashby v. Schertz-Cibolo-Universal ISD*, seeks to prevent all Texas school districts not yet involved in litigation from installing or maintaining these religious posters. Plaintiffs argue that pursuing individual cases district by district has become impractical given there are over 1,000 districts, more than 4,200 schools, and millions of students potentially exposed to these un

item.title: Oliver Bulleid and His Experimental Steam Locomotives: The Leader and the Turf Burner
item.description:
The article by Juan Manuel Grijalvo delves into the experimental spirit of engineer Oliver Bulleid, renowned for challenging the conventions of steam locomotive design as the age of steam power declined. Bulleid, famous for his bold ideas in British railways, ventured beyond traditional mechanical approaches in search of modernization. The piece begins with the 'Leader', a steam locomotive that appeared diesel-like due to its body design. Equipped with two driving cabs and twin sets of steam engines linked by roller chains, it represented a radical departure from standard steam technology. Despite its technical innovations—such as an efficient steam generator—the design suffered a severe flaw: its fireman worked in oppressive, unventilated heat exceeding fifty degrees Celsius. Strong union opposition to such working conditions led to abandonment of the project.
After the 'Leader' failure, Bulleid moved to Ireland, where Córas Iompair Éireann commissioned him to design a locomotive th

item.title: National Park Service Revises Free-Entry Days and Introduces International Visitor Fee in 2026
item.description: Starting January 1, 2026, the National Park Service (NPS) will implement significant changes to its fee structure and free-entry policies. International visitors without an annual pass will be required to pay $100 per person to enter the 11 most-visited national parks under the new 'America-first' initiative. For U.S. citizens and residents, several federal holidays will remain as free-entry days, while Juneteenth and Martin Luther King Jr. Day will no longer offer complimentary admission. New 'patriotic fee-free days' include President Donald Trump's birthday on June 14, Independence Day weekend (July 3–5), and the 110th birthday of the NPS on August 25. Other free-entry days for Americans include President’s Day, Memorial Day, Constitution Day, Theodore Roosevelt’s birthday, and Veterans Day. The changes are part of broader policies aimed at prioritizing American taxpayers, reducing diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives, and ensuring international visitors contribute to park m

item.title: The Economic Impact of the Ukrainian Diaspora on Ukraine and Host Countries
item.description: Ukraine faces one of the largest refugee crises in proportion to its population, a situation that has both humanitarian and economic implications. Millions of Ukrainians have fled the country since the onset of the war in February 2022, joining a long-standing diaspora that spans over 20 million people across more than 50 countries. Historically, Ukrainian emigration has occurred in waves, including late 19th-century agricultural migration to the Americas, post-World War II migration of Nazi collaborators to North America and Western Europe, and economic migration after the collapse of the USSR in 1991. Today, the diaspora contributes significantly to Ukraine's economy through remittances, which reached $17 billion in 2022 according to the World Bank, representing a crucial stabilizing force amid ongoing conflict. Countries hosting Ukrainian refugees, such as Poland, also benefit economically, with contributions to GDP estimated between 0.5 and 2.4 percentage points. Beyond financial a

item.title: India’s Artificial Intelligence Strategy Offers Mexico a Roadmap for Inclusive Innovation
item.description:
The article explores how India is rapidly transforming its digital landscape by investing heavily in artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure and inclusive innovation. In 2025, while global debates around AI’s risks and promises continued, India took decisive action, allocating large investments into GPUs, startups, education, and digital inclusion programs. This national effort aims to make AI a natural part of everyday life by 2026, fostering technological self-sufficiency and local innovation. The strategy relies on three core pillars: robust infrastructure, talent development, and inclusive technology adoption. By building its own computing capacity and promoting sovereign innovation, India seeks independence from foreign technological dependence.
The piece contrasts India’s progress with Mexico’s slower pace. It argues that Mexico has the talent and creativity needed for AI development but lacks a cohesive national strategy, sufficient infrastructure, and financial support for

item.title: Croatian Nun Hospitalized After Self-Inflicted Injuries
item.description: On December 3, 2025, Croatian media reported that 35-year-old nun Marija Tajana Zrno, known as Sister Zrno, had been stabbed in the Malesnica residential area of Zagreb. Initial reports sensationalized the incident, claiming the attacker shouted religious phrases and implying a foreign assailant, which stirred public concern. However, police investigations quickly revealed that the nun had purchased the knife herself and that her abdominal injuries were self-inflicted and superficial. No evidence of an outside attacker was found on surveillance footage. Sister Zrno is a well-known religious educator and football enthusiast in Croatia, having hosted programs on Catholic television and organized prayer initiatives for the Croatian national football team. Following the incident, she has been admitted to a psychiatric hospital for treatment. The authorities have filed a report against her, highlighting the incident as a case of self-harm rather than an external assault.

item.title: Venezuela's Strategic Use of Asymmetric Defense Against Technologically Superior Forces
item.description: The article analyzes Venezuela's strategic approach to modern asymmetric warfare, emphasizing that technological superiority alone does not guarantee victory. Western military planners have long assumed that dominance in GPS, satellite navigation, and digital mapping ensures operational control. However, Venezuela has focused on exploiting asymmetry rather than competing in technological parity. The country has developed systems capable of spoofing, interfering with, and rendering foreign geolocation tools unreliable, thereby disrupting precision in navigation, target designation, and coordinated military operations. Venezuelan defense doctrine prioritizes dispersal, camouflage, and environmental integration, leveraging forests, mountains, urban areas, and coastal regions to complicate adversaries’ reliance on satellite intelligence. By controlling the cognitive perception of terrain, Venezuela can neutralize superior forces, turning their technology into a vulnerability. The article a

item.title: EU Legal Measures and Controversies Regarding Support for Ukraine
item.description: The article discusses allegations that Ursula Von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, is manipulating European Union (EU) law to provide financial support to Ukraine, a country that is not an EU member and is facing severe economic difficulties. According to the report, Von der Leyen is allegedly using several tactics: declaring a financial emergency specific to Ukraine, framing support for Ukraine as existential for the EU, extending sanctions against Russia permanently, mandating financial institutions like Euroclear to release Russian assets, and approving key legal measures through qualified majority voting to bypass potential vetoes from member states such as Belgium. The article questions the legality of invoking Article 122 of the EU Treaty, which is designed to provide financial aid to EU member states in exceptional circumstances, highlighting that Ukraine is not a member. The author argues that these actions represent a bending of EU law and draws parallels to pr

item.title: ATLAS Collaboration Finds Strong Evidence of Higgs Boson Decaying into Muon–Antimuon Pair
item.description:
Researchers at CERN’s ATLAS experiment have reported new evidence showing that the Higgs boson, the fundamental particle linked to the Higgs field, can decay into a muon–antimuon pair. This breakthrough builds on years of work since the Higgs boson was first confirmed in 2012 at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). The new study, published in *Physical Review Letters*, combines data from the last two ATLAS runs, achieving a significance level of 3.4 standard deviations—an improvement over the 3.0 level previously reached by the CMS experiment.
This finding is crucial because it probes how the Higgs field gives mass to particles. In the Standard Model of particle physics, the Higgs boson’s interactions with particles, known as Yukawa couplings, determine their mass. While earlier studies confirmed these interactions for heavier third-generation particles such as top and bottom quarks and tau leptons, the new result strengthens evidence for the coupling to second-generation fermions like m

item.title: Gender-Based Violence Rises in Argentina Amid Milei’s Rollback of Women’s Rights
item.description: The article explores the worsening crisis of gender-based violence in Argentina under President Javier Milei. It opens with the murder of Fernanda Soledad Yramain, a young mother from Tucumán who repeatedly sought police protection from her violent partner before being killed in 2024. Her case exemplifies what many activists see as a systemic collapse of safeguards for women. Since taking office in December 2023, Milei’s administration has dismantled institutions and programs aimed at preventing and addressing violence against women, such as the Ministry of Women and the Acompañar program. Funding cuts have led to reduced staff on emergency hotlines and fewer prosecutorial offices dedicated to gender violence cases. Data from the province of Tucumán show a sharp decline in protection orders and an increase in femicides. Nationally, 295 femicides were recorded in 2024, with a surge in early 2025. item.title: How AI and Robotics Are Transforming Scientific Research and Mexico’s Role in It
item.description:
The article explores how artificial intelligence and robotics are rapidly reshaping global scientific research, particularly through their integration into laboratory environments. In the United Kingdom, several university labs have begun using autonomous robots guided by AI to perform chemistry and materials science experiments around the clock. This continuous and precise automation is accelerating discovery cycles and yielding immense data sets, enabling deeper correlations and faster innovation in areas like materials, pharmaceuticals, and energy technologies.
According to recent reports, these systems function through integrated platforms combining robotic arms, sensors, predictive models, and optimization algorithms. In this collaborative model, robots carry out physical tasks, AI determines the next hypotheses, and human scientists focus on designing research lines and validating outcomes. Such synergy greatly improves efficiency, turning traditional laboratories into advanced

item.title: Scientists map how the human brain learns and processes fear
item.description: Researchers from the Institut d’Investigacions Biomèdiques August Pi i Sunyer (IDIBAPS) in Barcelona have created the most detailed brain map to date showing how humans learn fear. Led by Enric Vilajosana, Miquel Àngel Fullana, and Joaquim Raduà, the study analyzed data from 42 previous experiments involving over 2,199 participants worldwide. They found that earlier inconsistencies in identifying brain areas involved in fear learning were due to limited statistical power rather than actual biological differences. By combining all available data, the team revealed that fear learning activates several interconnected brain regions, including the insula, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, premotor areas, anterior cingulate cortex, cerebellum, thalamus, caudate, and parts of the midbrain. Simultaneously, areas linked to the brain’s default mode network showed decreased activity, reflecting a shift of attention toward potential threats. item.title: Artificial Intelligence and the Telefónica Layoffs: The Contradictions of Capitalism in the Digital Era
item.description: The article examines how Telefónica’s restructuring, which includes one of the largest job cuts in its history—around 6,000 employees in Spain—reflects capitalism’s mounting contradictions under the rise of artificial intelligence (AI). Telefónica presents its workforce reduction as part of a strategic efficiency plan to cut debt and reallocate €3 billion by 2030 toward emerging sectors like AI and cybersecurity. However, the piece argues that this shift exposes deeper systemic issues: AI, while capable of producing abundance by automating work and optimizing resources, is deployed instead to preserve profitability and the capitalist order. Rather than being used to reduce working hours or redistribute productivity gains, technological advances are driving unemployment and social inequality. item.title: Putin Defends India’s Right to Buy Russian Energy Amid US Criticism
item.description:
During an exclusive interview with India Today ahead of his two-day visit to New Delhi, Russian President Vladimir Putin defended India’s right to maintain energy trade with Moscow despite pressure from the United States. He highlighted Washington’s continued purchase of uranium from Russia, which fuels American nuclear power plants, while at the same time urging New Delhi to reduce its imports of Russian oil. Putin pointed out the inconsistency in the US position, stating that if America has the right to buy fuel from Russia, India should enjoy the same privilege. Russia currently supplies about a quarter of the uranium used in US reactors, with estimated sales of $1.2 billion in 2025, up from $800 million in 2024.
Putin emphasized that Russia’s energy collaboration with India remains strong and unaffected by Western sanctions or the ongoing war in Ukraine. He described Prime Minister Narendra Modi as a reliable partner and credited his 'Make in India' initiative for deepening bilat

item.title: Belgium's F-35 Purchase Faces Serious Operational Challenges
item.description: In 2018, Belgium purchased 34 F-35 fighter jets at a cost of €5.6 billion, a controversial decision that excluded the French Rafale and highlighted Europe's dependence on the United States for defense. The controversy grew with an opinion piece by Joren Vermeersch, an advisor to the Belgian Defense Minister, who insulted France and argued that rejecting American weapons would marginalize Europe strategically. Recently, the first F-35 arrived in Belgium, but it faced technical problems, and the country's limited airspace caused further complications. Belgium's airspace is among the most restricted in Europe, making it difficult to conduct the necessary training for such advanced jets. The Belgian government is now seeking agreements with NATO allies like Italy, Norway, and the Netherlands to access broader training areas. This situation reveals Belgium's dependence on other nations for its defense preparedness, despite having invested heavily in one of the most expensive aircraft on the

item.title: Samsung Prioritizes Data Center Clients as Memory Costs Surge
item.description:
The article reports on a growing crisis in the memory chip market, where skyrocketing RAM prices have forced major manufacturers like Samsung to prioritize sales to higher-paying clients. According to sources, Samsung Semiconductor recently declined an order from Samsung Electronics, its own consumer electronics division, for DRAM chips destined for next-generation Galaxy smartphones. The reason is the ongoing 'AI bubble,' which has caused unprecedented demand for high-performance memory used in artificial intelligence data centers. With data center companies willing to pay premium prices, chipmakers such as Samsung, SK Hynix, and Micron are channeling resources toward that market segment.
Samsung Electronics, responsible for Galaxy devices, reportedly had to renegotiate short-term contracts at significantly increased prices after attempts to secure long-term supply agreements were rejected. item.title: Actor Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, Famous for 'Mortal Kombat', Passes Away at 75
item.description: Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, the Japanese American actor celebrated for his iconic portrayal of Shang Tsung in 'Mortal Kombat,' has passed away at the age of 75 due to complications from a stroke. Born in Japan and partly raised on U.S. military bases, Tagawa moved to Los Angeles where he developed his own martial arts style, Chu Shin. Discovered by director Bernardo Bertolucci, he gained international recognition with a role in the 1987 Oscar-winning film 'The Last Emperor,' and went on to appear in over 30 films. Tagawa often portrayed elegant and cunning villains, becoming a staple of action cinema. Beyond his film work, he served as a mentor to younger actors and martial artists, known for his generosity and charisma. His role as Shang Tsung became a cult classic, remembered for the line 'Your soul is mine,' and he reprised the character in the 2013 series 'Mortal Kombat: Legacy' and voiced him in the video game 'Mortal Kombat 11.' He also earned critical acclaim as trade minister Nobusuk

item.title: Africa's Strategic Minerals and the Global Race for Control
item.description: Africa has become the central stage of a fierce geopolitical and economic race over strategic minerals essential to powering modern technologies such as electric vehicle batteries, wind turbines, solar panels, and electronics. The continent holds vast reserves of key minerals—lithium, cobalt, copper, nickel, manganese, and rare earth elements—placing it at the crossroads of global industrial and political ambitions. The Democratic Republic of the Congo alone accounts for over 76% of the world’s cobalt supply, while Zimbabwe, Mali, and South Africa also host abundant reserves of lithium and other critical resources. China currently dominates the extraction, refining, and processing sectors, controlling up to 70% of global lithium and cobalt production chains. Its Belt and Road investments amount to more than $29 billion, much of it directed to mining infrastructure. item.title: Lawrence: Hegseth's story on boat strike hinges on a new 'fog of war' lie
item.description: The video appears to discuss claims made by Hegseth regarding a boat strike, suggesting that his story relies on misleading information framed as a 'fog of war.' The content likely analyzes or fact-checks these claims.

item.title: Analysis Reveals Most European Drone Sightings Were False Alarms
item.description:
Over recent months, numerous reports of unidentified drones near airports, ports, and military sites across Europe have caused alarm and speculation, particularly regarding possible Russian involvement. However, an investigation by the Dutch newspaper Trouw and the magazine Dronewatch analyzed 61 incidents across 11 countries between September 9 and November 27 and concluded that the vast majority lacked any tangible evidence of drones or foreign interference. Of those 61 sightings, 14 turned out to be other objects such as police helicopters or cargo planes, 41 had no verifiable proof or clear origin, while only three confirmed Russian drones were located in countries bordering Ukraine—Poland, Romania, and Moldova. This evidence does not substantiate claims of coordinated Russian activity in Western Europe.

item.title: Federal agents briefly detain woman claiming to be U.S. citizen in Key Largo
item.description: A woman driving through Key Largo was violently pulled from her car and detained by federal agents early Wednesday morning, according to a video recorded by Miami Herald reporter David Goodhue. The incident occurred near the Pink Plaza at Mile Marker 103.4 and involved several federal agencies, possibly including Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP). The woman, visibly distressed, shouted that she was a U.S. citizen and pleaded for help as agents handcuffed her. Witnesses, including Goodhue, described the event as both shocking and unnecessary, saying the situation escalated after officers apparently asked for identification that she did not have on hand. Local authorities from the Monroe County Sheriff’s Office were seen directing traffic but stated their role was limited to maintaining order. item.title: Mexico and Huawei Partner to Strengthen National Digital Talent and Innovation
item.description:
Mexico has taken a decisive step in advancing its digital transformation strategy through a new public-private partnership with Huawei. Announced on November 29, the initiative focuses on education and training in key technological areas such as artificial intelligence, data science, advanced networking, and cybersecurity. The agreement is set to benefit thousands of students, teachers, and developers through scholarships, technical certifications, and hands-on experience in innovation labs during 2025–2026. This move aims to enhance national expertise and prepare professionals for the growing demands of the digital economy.
Huawei will contribute by offering educational infrastructure, certified trainers, and proprietary course materials from its technology ecosystem, thereby improving the quality of training available in public institutions. item.title: Israel-backed Gaza Militia Leader Yasser Abu Shabab Killed in Rafah
item.description: Yasser Abu Shabab, leader of the Popular Forces militia and a key collaborator with Israeli forces, was reportedly killed on Thursday in Rafah, southern Gaza, an area under full Israeli control. Local and Israeli media outlets reported the death, though details on the perpetrator remain unclear, with some accounts suggesting an internal clash or shooting involving local families. Abu Shabab, a 35-year-old with a criminal background including convictions for theft and drug trafficking, escaped Hamas prison during early Israeli strikes and rebuilt his operations in eastern Rafah with Israeli arms, air cover, and coordination. His group faced widespread condemnation from Palestinian factions for looting humanitarian aid convoys, extorting civilians, attacking Palestinians, and alleged ties to ISIS, while aiding Israel's efforts against Hamas. item.title: Muslim-majority nations back China at the UN and reject U.S. narrative on Xinjiang
item.description:
The article reports that the United States' efforts to rally support against China at the United Nations over human rights concerns in Xinjiang have largely failed. Out of all UN member states, only fifteen countries — including the U.S., the U.K., Japan, and Israel — signed a joint declaration condemning China’s alleged abuses in Xinjiang. China’s counter-declaration, titled 'Opposition to the Politicization of Human Rights,' gathered 85 signatories, representing roughly half of the global population.
The report emphasizes that most Muslim-majority nations, including Saudi Arabia, Iran, Egypt, Nigeria, and Pakistan, chose to support China's stance instead of the U.S.-led declaration, revealing a major shift in diplomatic alignment. The piece argues that Washington’s attempt to portray itself as a defender of Muslim rights backfired, since traditional allies like Canada, France, Germany, and Italy abstained from signing. item.title: Italy temporarily halts new military support to Ukraine amid peace talks and funding strains
item.description:
The Italian government, led by Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, has decided to suspend further military support to Ukraine in light of ongoing peace negotiations and limited financial resources. Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani justified the move by saying it would be premature to join NATO’s new military procurement program for Ukraine, known as the Prioritised Ukraine Requirements List (PURL). The initiative allows NATO countries to jointly fund the purchase of U.S. weapons for Ukrainian defense. Tajani explained that if peace talks succeed and hostilities end, there will be no need for additional arms, but rather for security guarantees and reconstruction measures.
Rome’s decision marks the first explicit acknowledgment by a European government that continued military assistance might be counterproductive while ceasefire negotiations are under way. item.title: Media Silence over Palestine Action Prisoners on Hunger Strike in the UK
item.description:
The article by Jonathan Cook, published on Rafael Poch de Feliu’s blog, denounces the total absence of media coverage in the United Kingdom of six Palestine Action activists currently on hunger strike. These activists, imprisoned for attacking British arms factories supplying weapons to Israel, have been retroactively labeled as 'terrorists' under the UK’s expansive anti-terrorism legislation after the government banned their organization. Their protest aims to draw attention to what they consider illegal imprisonment and complicity in genocide in Gaza.
Cook contrasts the current silence with the 1980s IRA hunger strikes, which received broad and sustained media attention. He argues that today’s corporate and state-aligned press avoids coverage that might embarrass the government or expose repression against political dissent. item.title: Canada’s Historical and Ongoing Ties with Former Nazis and Far-Right Elements
item.description:
The article from MPR21 argues that Canada has historically provided refuge and even legitimacy to former Nazis and fascists, especially those from Eastern Europe. It begins by referencing a statement from historian Irving Abella, who noted that in postwar Canada, having an SS tattoo could serve as proof of being anti-communist—something valued during the Cold War. The text links this attitude to a broader Western pattern of sheltering fascist and Nazi collaborators after World War II, citing examples such as Otto Skorzeny and Stefano Delle Chiaie in Spain.
The piece focuses heavily on Canada’s admission of Ukrainian members of the Waffen-SS Galicia Division and the controversial 2023 parliamentary tribute to Yaroslav Hunka, a veteran of that division. It argues that Canada not only accepted these individuals but also deliberately concealed their presence, refusing to release a list of Nazi war criminals who settled in the country. item.title: YouTube deletes Palestinian human rights videos following U.S. sanctions
item.description: The article reports that YouTube, under pressure from U.S. sanctions imposed by the Trump administration, has deleted the accounts of three Palestinian human rights organizations — Al Haq, Al Mezan Center for Human Rights, and the Palestinian Center for Human Rights (PCHR). These groups had published more than 700 videos documenting alleged Israeli war crimes in Gaza and the West Bank, including civilian killings, home demolitions, and testimonies from victims. The decision followed new U.S. sanctions targeting groups cooperating with the International Criminal Court (ICC), which has been investigating Israeli officials, including Benjamin Netanyahu and Yoav Gallant, for alleged war crimes. According to YouTube’s statement, the deletions were part of compliance with U.S. sanctions law, but human rights advocates condemned the move as censorship and complicity in silencing Palestinian voices. item.title: Chinese Zhuque 3 Rocket Launches Successfully While First Stage Landing Fails
item.description: On December 3, 2025, the Chinese private aerospace company LandSpace successfully launched the first Zhuque 3 rocket, marking the first Chinese orbital vehicle with a partially reusable first stage. The mission, named 'Land to Infinity,' lifted off at 04:00 UTC from Launch Complex 96B in the Dongfeng Commercial Aerospace Testing Area near Jiuquan, Inner Mongolia. The second stage successfully reached orbit with a simulated payload, achieving an initial orbit of 142 x 402 km at a 56.95° inclination. However, the first stage failed to land on its dedicated platform 390 km away, experiencing an explosion during the final landing burn. Despite the setback, the stage reached an apogee of 120 km and performed a 46-second braking burn, demonstrating significant progress for a private Chinese aerospace company. item.title: Belgium Faces Major Labor Strikes Amid Political and Economic Challenges
item.description: Belgium is experiencing a deepening social and political crisis, exacerbated by recent labor unrest. The government is under pressure from Europe regarding Russian-held funds, while internally it struggles to function as a coalition of five disparate parties. Workers and pensioners staged a three-day strike, marking the largest mobilization since the famous 1960-1961 'Strike of the Century.' The strikes reflect growing dissatisfaction with working conditions and the government's austerity policies, which prioritize budget cuts over social welfare. The article compares current events to the historic strike, highlighting the political nature of past labor movements that opposed both government austerity and broader structural inequalities. Despite strong street mobilizations, the government continues to pursue austerity and maintain control, with minimal engagement with unions. The piece suggests that without a political dimension, modern strikes risk being ineffective and failing to ach

item.title: How a Colonial Rat Bounty in Hanoi Backfired and Spread Disease
item.description: In early 1900s Hanoi, French colonial officials introduced a rat bounty program to curb plague outbreaks, offering a coin for every rat tail brought in. Initially, it seemed successful, but the policy quickly backfired. Hunters often cut off tails and released the rats to breed more, while some even raised rats deliberately for profit. This perverse incentive caused the rat population to increase, exposing hunters to greater plague risk and undermining public health efforts. The broader context involved unequal urban planning: European quarters received modern sewers, while Vietnamese neighborhoods were left with open gutters, exacerbating rat infestations. Experts highlight this as an early example of Goodhart’s Law, showing how poorly designed incentives can lead to unintended consequences. Modern parallels exist, such as bounties on rodents or invasive species in Jakarta and South Dakota, which similarly risk encouraging exploitation rather than solving the problem. The article emph

item.title: Congress Releases 2020 Photos and Videos of Jeffrey Epstein’s Caribbean Island for Transparency
item.description: On December 3, 2025, House Democrats released previously unseen images and videos of Jeffrey Epstein’s private Caribbean island, providing insight into the environment where he allegedly trafficked young girls. The materials, captured in 2020, a year after Epstein died in jail, show various areas of the property, including bedrooms, an office or library, a dentist chair room, and a chalkboard with words like 'fin', 'intellectual', 'deception', and 'power'. The release follows ongoing investigations into Epstein's crimes, including a 2022 settlement in which the US Virgin Islands attorney general secured over $100 million from Epstein’s estate after alleging sexual abuse and trafficking at Little St James, one of his two islands. Congressional leaders emphasized that while the images do not reveal new evidence, their release is part of a broader effort to maintain public transparency and pressure on the Justice Department to release additional files by the December 19 deadline. item.title: CDMX and Hidalgo Partner to Share Digital Tools for Government Modernization
item.description: On November 27, 2025, the governments of Mexico City (CDMX) and the State of Hidalgo officially announced a partnership aimed at modernizing public administration through digital innovation. The agreement allows Hidalgo to adopt a range of advanced digital platforms and systems developed by the Digital Agency for Public Innovation (ADIP) in Mexico City. These include digital authentication, unique digital records, remote procedures, digital citizen services, open data systems, and automated chatbots. By implementing these tools, Hidalgo aims to streamline administrative processes, reduce bureaucracy, enhance transparency, and improve citizen access to public services. For Mexico City, the collaboration reinforces its status as a national leader in digital government services. Hidalgo benefits by avoiding the cost and time required to develop its own systems, enabling more efficient allocation of resources. Expected advantages include easier access to public services, increased accounta

item.title: Bipartisan Group of House Members Pushes Vote to Ban Congressional Stock Trading
item.description: A group of House Republicans and Democrats, including Rep. Anna Paulina Luna (R-Fla.) and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), have joined forces to advance legislation banning members of Congress from trading stocks. Using a discharge petition—a procedural tactic previously employed to release the Jeffrey Epstein files—the coalition seeks to bypass House Speaker Mike Johnson, who has limited floor votes on certain issues. Once a discharge petition gains enough signatures and seven legislative days pass, a vote is automatically scheduled. The push reflects growing public concern over lawmakers using insider knowledge for personal financial gain, an issue highlighted during previous administrations but delayed under former Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Rep. Tim Burchett (R-Tenn.) described the coalition as surprising given its ideological diversity. Earlier attempts by Luna to use a discharge petition for proxy voting rights were blocked by Johnson. The bipartisan approach mirrors tactics us

item.title: European Cities and NGOs Warn Against Lowering Vehicle Safety Standards to US Levels
item.description: European cities including Paris, Brussels, and Amsterdam, along with more than 75 civil society organizations, have warned EU officials about the potential risks of adopting lower US vehicle standards. The warning comes after a recent EU-US trade agreement indicated mutual recognition of each other's automotive regulations. EU safety standards have been credited with reducing European road deaths by 36% since 2010, while US road deaths rose by 30% in the same period, with significant increases in pedestrian and cyclist fatalities. European regulations mandate life-saving technologies such as pedestrian protection, automated emergency braking, and lane-keeping assistance. Aligning with weaker US standards could undermine decades of progress in road safety and public health. Moreover, the EU is preparing to implement stricter limits on vehicle-related pollution, whereas US rules are being relaxed. Accepting lower standards could increase European exposure to harmful pollutants linked to

item.title: Canadian Photographer Captures Rare Toad Mutation with Eyes in Its Mouth
item.description: In 1992, Canadian photographer Scott Gardner discovered a toad in Burlington County, Ontario, with an extremely rare genetic mutation: its eyes were located inside its mouth. Gardner photographed the toad and the image was published in The Hamilton Spectator, quickly gaining attention in both Canada and the United States. The toad's unusual appearance baffled scientists, but it has been confirmed as a real phenomenon known as a macromutation. This type of mutation can significantly alter an organism's structure, and in amphibians, it sometimes affects limbs or other body parts. In this case, the mutation caused the toad's eye sockets to be absent, resulting in the eyes growing from its palate. While the exact cause of such mutations remains unclear, scientists suspect a parasitic trematode infection may play a role. Despite its strange appearance, the toad can live a normal life, as its eyes remain functional. Interestingly, even normally developed frogs and toads can retract their eye

item.title: Geopolitical Maneuvers and the Uncertain Path to Peace in Ukraine
item.description:
The article by Rafael Poch de Feliu examines the complex and contradictory dynamics surrounding current peace discussions about the war in Ukraine. It highlights statements by Vladimir Putin asserting that Russia is not seeking war with Europe but is prepared for it if necessary, contrasting this readiness with what he describes as Europe’s 'illusion' of defeating Russia. The piece details NATO’s increasing aggressiveness, citing potential preemptive strikes on Moscow and ongoing maritime drone attacks against Russian cargo ships allegedly orchestrated by British military personnel in Ukraine.
Poch explains that contacts between Putin and U.S. envoys—specifically Donald Trump’s associates Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner—reflect internal divisions within the American establishment about how to handle Russia. The article argues that Trump's negotiations with Moscow are pragmatic rather than pacifist, seeking to save resources, shift focus to Asia, and maintain pressure on Russia and Chi

item.title: The Ukraine Conflict Approaches a Formal End, But Tensions and Hybrid Warfare May Persist
item.description: The news article reports that recent Russian advances in Ukraine, including the capture of Pokrovsk and Volchansk, indicate a gradual decline in Ukrainian operational capabilities. Although the territory gained in recent weeks is modest relative to Ukraine’s total size, these advances are more resilient due to the prevalence of drones, which limit rapid tank movements but strengthen occupied positions. Ukrainian commanders have signaled that they may resist political agreements involving territorial withdrawal, but the article notes that actual military defiance is unlikely without central supply interruptions. The author argues that the formal conclusion of the conflict could arrive by spring or summer, yet warns that this will not be a true end. The piece highlights a potential long-term alliance between radicalized Ukrainian forces and European militaristic agendas, which may result in permanent hybrid warfare, including sabotage, cyberattacks, and covert operations. item.title: Inquiry reveals UK special forces executed civilians including children in Afghanistan
item.description: A senior British military officer testified in the UK's Afghanistan war crimes inquiry that an elite SAS unit deliberately executed detainees and civilians, including toddlers shot while in bed. The testimony alleges a systemic 'kill policy' by the UK Special Forces unit UKSF1 and describes cover-ups by senior commanders and a failure to properly investigate these war crimes. The inquiry revealed incidents where the number of enemy killed far exceeded weapons recovered, casting doubt on official reports. A particularly disturbing case cited was the shooting of two young children and their parents during a nighttime raid in Nimruz province in 2012. The officer described a culture within UKSF1 of casual killings and data manipulation to conceal unlawful acts. This evidence adds to growing allegations of British war crimes in Afghanistan between 2010 and 2013, highlighting the suppression of investigations by military leadership and the Ministry of Defence.

item.title: Burkina Faso Revives SN-BRAFASO Brewery to Generate Thousands of Jobs
item.description: After over 15 years of inactivity, Burkina Faso has revitalized the SN-BRAFASO brewery with a major public investment. The factory, located in Komsilga, was reopened following an overhaul, and is set to produce 600,000 hectoliters annually. The reopening marks a significant step in utilizing local raw materials like maize, sorghum, and rice, essential to the country's agriculture. The rehabilitation, costing over 17 billion CFA francs, also brings new job opportunities, with 300 direct jobs and an expected 20,000 indirect jobs across sectors such as logistics, distribution, and agriculture. President Ibrahim Traoré expressed his pride, calling the reopening a victory against imperialism and a symbol of the resilience of Burkina Faso's people. The factory plans to launch two flagship beverages, BRAF'OR and BRAFASO, and expand to produce soft drinks and mineral water. The move aligns with the government's push for economic autonomy and local industrial growth.

item.title: The Fabergé Winter Egg Sells for $30.2 Million at Christie’s Auction
item.description: The renowned Fabergé Winter Egg, considered one of the most exquisite Imperial Eggs ever created, has resurfaced after being lost for over two decades. Originally purchased in 2002 by a Qatari prince for $9.6 million, it sold at Christie’s London for £22.9 million ($30.2 million), surpassing expectations. Out of the 50 Fabergé Imperial Eggs commissioned for Russian Tsarinas, only 44 survive today, with just six held privately. Designed by Alma Pihl, granddaughter of Fabergé’s workmaster, the Winter Egg is adorned with more than 3,200 rose-cut diamonds and intricately carved rock crystal, platinum, nephrite, and gold details. Its hidden surprise—a platinum and diamond trellis basket containing quartz wood anemones and garnets—is emblematic of Fabergé’s signature craftsmanship. The egg’s design was inspired by the snowflakes seen through Pihl’s workshop window and is part of the Winter Jewels series, initially created for Swedish-Russian tycoon Emanuel Nobel. Over the years, the egg trav

item.title: Rare Corncrake Rescued on Cruise Ship by Passengers
item.description: A rare and endangered corncrake was rescued by passengers aboard the Sky Princess cruise ship while it traveled toward Portland, Dorset. The bird, listed as red by the RSPB due to its declining population in the UK, was discovered shivering under a hot tub step on the 16th deck by Charlene Halsey and her daughters. Observing its distress, the family took the bird into their cabin, kept it warm, and cared for it overnight. They named it Aaron Burrd after the musical Hamilton. Once the ship docked, Derek Davey, a specialist in seabird rescue and rehabilitation, took responsibility for the corncrake. He noted that the bird likely boarded the ship while it was in the Mediterranean and highlighted the challenges of providing suitable overwintering conditions before the corncrake can return north to its breeding grounds. Corncrakes are highly secretive birds, primarily living in tall grass, with a distinctive 'crex crex' call. Their population has sharply declined since the 1970s, making the

item.title: Historical and Mythological Stories Surrounding the Apple
item.description: This article explores the fascinating and sometimes dark history of the apple, highlighting its cultural, literary, and mythological significance. It begins by explaining the etymology of the word 'apple,' tracing it back to the Latin term 'malum' and the Roman botanist Gaius Matius, whose cultivated variety influenced the modern Spanish term. The article then discusses the apple in the context of the Biblical story of the Garden of Eden, noting that the original text never specifies the fruit and that the Latin translation by Saint Jerome created the association by using the word 'malum,' which also means 'evil.' Next, the apple's role in Greek mythology is recounted, focusing on the golden apple of discord that sparked the Trojan War. Finally, the story of Snow White is examined, contrasting the Grimm brothers' original dark tale with the more familiar modern version. The piece emphasizes the apple's recurring presence in human storytelling as both a symbol of temptation and a cataly

item.title: Dramatic Decline in Child Mortality Over Human History
item.description: For most of human history, around half of all children died before reaching puberty. In contrast, by 2020, global child mortality had dropped to just 4.3%, with countries like Japan and Norway achieving rates as low as 0.3%. This extraordinary reduction is attributed to advancements in nutrition, clean water, sanitation, neonatal healthcare, vaccinations, medicines, and significant decreases in poverty, conflicts, and famine. Personal anecdotes shared by readers illustrate how infant and child mortality was a common experience only a century ago, with multiple generations experiencing the loss of siblings or children. Modern medicine and public health improvements have fundamentally transformed human lifespan, largely by preventing early deaths rather than prolonging life at older ages. Experts argue that investing in public health measures could further enhance global health outcomes. The article also notes that, despite the success of vaccines in drastically reducing childhood mortal

item.title: ESA Releases First True-Color Global Mosaic of Mars from Orbit
item.description: A new high-resolution true-color mosaic of Mars has been produced by the European Space Agency (ESA) using the High Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC) aboard its Mars Express mission, which has been orbiting the planet for over two decades. Unlike previous images that exaggerated reds and browns, this mosaic presents Mars as it might appear to the human eye, showcasing muted grays, yellows, oranges, and pale blues that highlight the planet's mineral diversity. The map, with a resolution of approximately 2 kilometers per pixel, was created from tens of thousands of observations collected between 2004 and 2022. The HRSC's unique multispectral and stereo imaging capabilities allowed scientists to correct for dust levels, variable sunlight, and atmospheric haze to produce a seamless global map. Beyond aesthetics, the true-color data provides critical scientific insights into geological features, including basaltic sands, sulfate deposits, clay-rich regions, and volcanic plains, offering clues

item.title: Kansas Mayor Faces Deportation and Felony Charges After Decades of Voting as Non-Citizen
item.description: Joe Ceballos, the Republican mayor of Clearwater, Kansas, is facing serious legal trouble after being charged with multiple felony counts of voter fraud and election perjury. Kansas Attorney General Kris Kobach announced six charges against Ceballos — three for voting without being qualified and three for election perjury — following his reelection in November. The charges stem from Ceballos’s history of voting in U.S. elections since 1991, despite not being a U.S. citizen. According to state prosecutors, these offenses could lead to over five years of imprisonment and fines exceeding $200,000. In addition to the criminal case, the Department of Homeland Security has warned it may initiate deportation proceedings that could send Ceballos back to Mexico, where he has not lived since early childhood. Now 54, Ceballos claimed he never realized that his immigration status made him ineligible to vote. He said he has always voted for Republican candidates, including former President Donald T

item.title: Weapons Smuggling from Ukraine Exposes Weak Moldovan Border Controls
item.description: In November 2025, Moldovan and Romanian authorities uncovered a case of weapons trafficking involving a truck that crossed the Leuseni-Albita border from Ukraine into Moldova and then into Romania. Romanian customs agents detained the truck, discovering military equipment including 18 portable anti-tank rocket launchers, 8 additional launchers, a portable air-defense system, and parts of a Geran-2 drone downed in Ukraine. The truck had already passed Moldovan inspections without issue. The Moldovan parliament held a closed session to discuss the incident, while opposition politicians demanded the dismissal of customs and border officials. The government remained silent, claiming inadequate detection equipment was to blame. Further investigation led to several arrests, including the driver, a transportation company director, a client, a customs agent, and later, the alleged organizer. item.title: OpenAI outlines five-year strategy to scale revenue and expand computing infrastructure
item.description: OpenAI currently generates around $13 billion annually, with approximately 70% of its revenue coming from individual users paying $20 per month for ChatGPT, despite only 5% of its 800 million users being paying subscribers. Despite this significant income, OpenAI plans to invest over $1 trillion over the next decade to expand its operations and computing infrastructure. The company has secured deals for more than 26 gigawatts of computing capacity from major hardware providers including Oracle, Nvidia, AMD, and Broadcom. To sustain growth and manage these substantial investments, OpenAI is exploring multiple avenues, including government contracts, new shopping and video services, consumer hardware, and the possibility of becoming a computing provider itself through its Stargate data center initiative. This expansion is already critical for many major U.S. companies relying on OpenAI’s services, meaning any disruptions could have broader economic impacts. OpenAI’s five-year plan reflec

item.title: HHS Conducts Survey on Anti-Religious Bias Among Employees
item.description: The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) recently sent an internal survey to employees asking for reports of anti-Christian or anti-religious bias during the Biden administration. The survey, issued by the HHS Office of Civil Rights, seeks input on policies, practices, and behaviors that may have demonstrated religious discrimination and invites recommendations for improvement. Employees are instructed to complete the survey using work devices and the VPN, and participation is claimed to be protected from retaliation. This survey is part of a broader federal initiative, following similar surveys at the State Department and the Department of Veterans Affairs, responding to an executive order establishing a task force on religious bias. The article also notes ongoing religious events within other federal agencies, including prayer services at the Department of Defense and Department of Labor, emphasizing Christianity. item.title: Declassified Files Reveal NYPD ‘Red Squad’ Surveillance of Civil Rights Activists
item.description: The article reveals the release of declassified surveillance files from the New York Police Department's Special Services Division, historically known as the 'Red Squad.' These files include candid photos and reports monitoring civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. and his associates during key moments in the 1960s, including his visit to New York City shortly after winning the Nobel Peace Prize. Despite public praise from city officials, the files show a deep police distrust and covert surveillance driven by alignment with FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover’s hostile views of King as a communist and liar. The New York police engaged in extensive spying, disruption, and sabotage efforts against civil rights activists long before the FBI's infamous COINTELPRO program. Such local surveillance tactics continued into recent decades, targeting progressive protest movements and demonstrating ongoing coordination between local police and federal authorities. item.title: 1932 US Communist Party Campaign Poster Advocating Black Rights and Self-Determination
item.description: The 1932 U.S. Communist Party campaign poster promoted William Z. Foster for president and James W. Ford for vice president, emphasizing racial equality and political self-determination for Black Americans. James W. Ford was the first African American to appear on a national ticket, highlighting the Communist Party's efforts to position itself as a home for Black voters during a period of widespread segregation. The poster also featured a map of the 'Black Belt,' areas in the Deep South with large African American populations, advocating their right to self-governance, a radical stance compared to mainstream U.S. politics at the time. Foster, a prominent labor organizer and three-time presidential candidate, suffered a heart attack mid-campaign, leaving Ford to handle most public campaigning. Although the Communist Party received only 0.23% of the popular vote, its platform addressed issues largely ignored by major parties, including federal unemployment insurance, anti-lynching laws,

item.title: Poland Faces Ongoing Cybersecurity Threats from Russia
item.description: Polish Digital Affairs Minister Krzysztof Gawkowski stated that Poland is engaged in a continuous cyberwar with Russia, emphasizing that cyber operations never rest unlike conventional military campaigns. Speaking at a digital conference in Berlin organized by the German-Polish Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Gawkowski highlighted Poland's awareness of potential cyberattacks from Russian intelligence, particularly the GRU, targeting Polish networks. This statement follows the arrest of a Russian suspect in Krakow, accused of hacking several Polish companies' systems, manipulating their data, and potentially being linked to other cybercrimes across the European Union. Gawkowski also met with Germany's Minister of Digital Transformation and Administrative Modernization, Karsten Wildberger, to discuss European digital autonomy and support for local tech companies. The heightened vigilance of Poland against cyber threats is largely due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, with the governm

item.title: President Trump Appears Drowsy During Cabinet Meeting Amid Questions About Health and Fitness
item.description: President Donald Trump, 79, was observed repeatedly nodding off during a Tuesday Cabinet meeting, struggling to remain alert while receiving updates from his Cabinet members. This incident follows a New York Times report highlighting a notable decline in his energy and activity compared to his first term, prompting visible frustration from the president. Trump’s drowsiness during long meetings mirrors prior occurrences, including an international briefing with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Riyadh. The article underscores growing public concern about Trump's physical and mental stamina as the oldest president in U.S. history. The report also touches on other controversies within his administration, such as Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth’s involvement in a September 2 boat strike in the Caribbean, which reportedly left survivors dead in a follow-up attack, drawing scrutiny from Republican lawmakers. item.title: France launches a voluntary national service program aiming to strengthen ties between youth and armed forces
item.description:
The French government is preparing to introduce a renewed form of national military service, presented as part of a broader civic and professional education initiative. Proposed by General Pierre Schill and endorsed by President Emmanuel Macron, the plan seeks to combine volunteerism with military training, targeting primarily 18- to 19-year-olds. Macron stated that this 'voluntary national service' will strengthen national resilience and reinforce connections between young citizens and the armed forces. Participants will serve for ten months, engaging in domestic defense missions such as Operation Sentinelle or assisting according to their skills in fields like logistics, IT, or catering. They will receive lodging, meals, laundry services, and a monthly stipend of about 800 euros. Those who wish can later enlist in the professional army, with prior service recognized as experience.

item.title: Abbott FreeStyle Libre 3 Sensors Linked to Multiple Injuries and Deaths Due to Inaccurate Readings
item.description: Abbott Diabetes Care has reported that approximately 3 million FreeStyle Libre 3 and FreeStyle Libre 3 Plus sensors may provide inaccurately low glucose readings. According to the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), this issue has been associated with at least seven deaths and more than 700 serious injuries worldwide. Incorrect readings can result in unsafe treatment decisions, such as skipping insulin doses or consuming excessive carbohydrates, posing severe health risks. About 60 injuries have occurred in the US, none of which were fatal. Abbott confirmed that the manufacturing problem has been resolved and production continues, with no expected supply disruptions. Patients are advised to check their sensors at FreeStyleCheck.com and replace any affected devices free of charge. Diabetes affects roughly 38 million Americans, representing about one in ten people in the US, and remains the seventh leading cause of death nationwide. item.title: Israeli attacks in Gaza during ceasefire leave 356 Palestinians dead and over 900 injured, Gaza Health Ministry reports
item.description:
The Gaza Health Ministry has reported that 356 Palestinians have been killed and 908 injured since the Gaza ceasefire took effect on October 11, 2025. Despite the truce, Israeli attacks have continued in several areas of the Gaza Strip. In the last 24 hours alone, three additional Palestinians were reported dead. Authorities have also retrieved 607 bodies from earlier bombardments and warned that more victims remain trapped under rubble and inaccessible roads due to security risks and lack of rescue capacity.
According to the ministry, these new figures bring the total death toll in Gaza since the start of the Israeli offensive in October 2023 to at least 70,103, with more than 170,985 wounded. The report also cites a recent study from the Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research, which provides a grim reassessment of the human cost of the Gaza war. item.title: Edomex Proposes Constitutional Reform to Establish a Permanent Digital Government Framework
item.description:
The article describes a significant step toward digital governance in the State of Mexico, marked by the presentation of a constitutional reform initiative on November 28, 2025. Governor Delfina Gómez Álvarez submitted the proposal to the LXII Legislature, aiming to include principles of administrative simplification, digital services, regulatory best practices, and strengthened public-sector technological capabilities directly into the state constitution. By giving these concepts constitutional status, all branches of government, municipalities, autonomous bodies, and their respective agencies would be obligated to adopt and maintain coordinated digital governance models and tools.
A central element of the proposal is the dissolution of the existing State Commission for Regulatory Improvement and the elimination of its current regulatory law. Its responsibilities, resources, and operational structure would be absorbed by a new entity: the Digital Agency of the State of Mexico (ADEM)

item.title: The Role of Modern Supercomputing in Science, Government, and National Strategy
item.description:
The article explores the growing importance of supercomputers in shaping scientific progress, industrial innovation, and governmental decision-making. As technological acceleration intensifies, supercomputing has re-emerged as a strategic asset for countries seeking scientific leadership and digital autonomy. Supercomputers, capable of performing trillions of operations per second through massively parallel architectures, rely on high-speed interconnects and a balanced combination of CPUs and GPUs. These hardware configurations allow them to tackle complex simulations impossible for conventional systems, supporting fields such as climate modeling, molecular analysis, and large-scale artificial intelligence training.
The article compares landmark systems like Frontier, Aurora, LUMI, and MareNostrum 5, highlighting how their distinct architectures address diverse needs—from genomic research to critical infrastructure modeling. Energy consumption is presented as a central challenge, as t

item.title: Ron Gilbert Explains His Shift from Adventure Games to Action Survival Design
item.description:
The article profiles veteran game designer Ron Gilbert as he discusses his unexpected shift from classic point-and-click adventure games to the action-survival genre with his latest release, *Death by Scrolling*. Gilbert, best known for creating *Maniac Mansion*, *Monkey Island*, and *Thimbleweed Park*, explains that the pivot was not as abrupt as it seemed. Although he is most closely associated with narrative-driven adventures, he has also worked on reflex-based titles such as the *Backyard Sports* series and *DeathSpank*. His inspiration for the new project stemmed from his appreciation for modern action roguelites like *Binding of Isaac* and *Dead Cells*.
Originally, Gilbert attempted to develop a large open-world action RPG inspired by *The Legend of Zelda*, but the ambition proved unrealistic for a small three-person team. item.title: How billionaires stole America's elections
item.description: The video explores how the wealth of billionaires impacts American elections, examining their role in funding political campaigns and shaping policies to benefit their interests.

item.title: UN Committee against Torture Issues Human Rights Findings on Albania, Argentina, Bahrain, and Israel
item.description: The UN Committee against Torture (CAT) released its findings after reviewing the human rights practices of Albania, Argentina, Bahrain, and Israel. For Albania, concerns focus on the 2023 Protocol with Italy on migrant detention facilities and the lack of clarity around jurisdiction and independent monitoring. The Committee urged Albania to ensure compliance with the Convention against Torture and improve investigation and accountability for police-related torture and ill-treatment. In Argentina, the prolonged detention in police facilities and the poor conditions were heavily criticized, along with the unclear and potentially excessive use of force regulations. The Committee called for urgent reforms and better training. Bahrain was noted for routine use of torture to extract confessions and severe reprisals against human rights defenders and critics, with calls for thorough investigations and protection measures. item.title: US Requests Lebanon Return Undetonated GBU-39 Bomb to Prevent Sensitive Technology Transfer
item.description:
According to a report from The Jerusalem Post, the United States has formally asked Lebanon to return an undetonated GBU-39 bomb that allegedly failed to explode during the recent Israeli airstrikes in southern Lebanon. Washington fears that the bomb’s recovery by Hezbollah or Lebanese authorities could result in its components being transferred to Russia or China, both of which have shown interest in advanced Western military technology. The GBU-39, also known as the Small Diameter Bomb (SDB), is a precision-guided glide bomb developed by Boeing. While it lacks an engine, it can deploy wings and glide more than 110 kilometers to hit its target with high accuracy. It is typically launched from aircraft such as the F-15 or F-35.
The concern reportedly centers on the bomb’s guidance and navigation systems, which contain sensitive microelectronics and proprietary targeting algorithms. Similar munitions have played key roles in Western military operations, and reverse-engineering one coul

item.title: Interactive Three-Body Simulator Featuring 2D and 3D Periodic Orbits
item.description: Trisolar Chaos presents an interactive N-body gravitational simulator designed to study the complex dynamics of the three-body problem. Unlike the two-body problem, the motion of three gravitationally interacting bodies cannot be solved analytically, making numerical simulations essential. The simulator calculates pairwise gravitational forces using Newton's law of universal gravitation and offers a choice of integration methods: the symplectic Velocity Verlet method for long-term energy conservation and the 4th-order Runge-Kutta method for short-term accuracy. Users can explore famous preset 2D orbits, including the Figure-8 choreography, Lagrange triangular configuration, and orbits from the Šuvakov-Dmitrašinović database. In addition, the simulator incorporates over 10,000 new 3D periodic orbits discovered by Li and Liao (2025), including choreographic and 'piano-trio' orbits. item.title: Gaza Humanitarian Crisis Worsens Amid Limited Aid and Fuel Shortages
item.description: Israeli authorities have claimed they are providing Gaza with large quantities of tents, blankets, and fuel in preparation for winter. However, reports from Palestinian officials, UN agencies, and field data contradict these claims. Since the ceasefire on October 10, only 34% of expected supplies have entered Gaza, with limited humanitarian trucks and fuel shipments. Cooking gas deliveries account for just 15% of the required supply, while diesel fuel deliveries are at only 12% of planned levels. Approximately 9,000 trucks carrying tents and other aid remain blocked outside Gaza, including 6,000 from the UN. Gaza’s urgent need exceeds 300,000 tents, and displaced families are suffering from flooding, cold, and unsanitary conditions due to insufficient shelter materials. UNRWA confirmed that winter aid in its warehouses in Egypt has not been allowed into Gaza, and the UN Secretary-General’s office warned that obstacles to humanitarian assistance persist. item.title: China and the U.S. Trade Accusations Over the Seizure of 127,000 Bitcoin Linked to Criminal Networks
item.description: The article examines escalating tensions between China and the United States over the origins and handling of a massive Bitcoin haul valued at around $13 billion. The controversy began when blockchain analytics firm Arkham Intelligence revealed that LuBian, a major Bitcoin mining pool controlling roughly 6% of global hashrate, had been hacked in December 2020. The attacker allegedly exploited weak private key generation on LuBian’s systems, draining over 90% of its Bitcoin holdings. For four years, the stolen funds remained untouched, fueling speculation that the perpetrator was a well-resourced actor. In 2024 the funds moved to a new wallet, and by 2025 the U.S. Department of Justice claimed to have seized the stash while indicting Chen Zhi, head of the Cambodian Prince Group, known for large-scale ‘pig-butchering’ scams involving trafficking and forced labor. The DOJ argues the Bitcoin represents proceeds of Chen’s criminal activities, many of whose victims were Americans. China, how

item.title: An In-Depth Overview of Linux Input Device Architecture
item.description: This article offers a detailed examination of the Linux input stack, breaking down its architecture from hardware to user-space components. It divides input handling into kernel-level and user-space levels, highlighting key parts like the input core subsystem and device drivers in the kernel, along with the event abstraction layer (evdev), devtmpfs, sysfs, and procfs. The user-space side involves udev for device management and module loading via MODALIAS, as well as libraries like libinput and XKB used by graphical servers and compositors to interpret input events. The kernel input core manages device lifecycles, event diffusion to handlers, and abstracts device-specific protocols into standardized formats such as evdev. It also describes the sysfs filesystem exposing kernel objects and properties, and the hierarchy of kernel objects representing buses, devices, and drivers, essential for plug-and-play functionality.
